jumping.title: Jumping
jumping.subtitle: Jump-rope tracker with trends and calories
jumping.summary: A minimal tracker for jump-rope workouts: quick logging, streaks, and progress. Designed to reduce friction and make training feel rewarding.
responsibilities: Low-friction logging flow with auto-detection hooks
Session timelines, personal bests, and streaks
Lightweight dark theme; haptics for feedback
problems: Manual logging felt tedious; users skipped entries
Inconsistent feedback reduced motivation over time
solutions: One-tap logging with smart defaults and auto-detection
Streaks, personal bests, and haptic cues for instant feedback

navippon.title: Navippon
navippon.subtitle: Japan travel guide — discovery, itineraries, culture
navippon.summary: Navippon helps travelers plan and explore Japan with curated places, a unified map + list view, and day-by-day itineraries. We built the brand, product, and launch plan end-to-end as a two-person team.
goals: Create a lightweight planner that balances culture, food, and logistics.
Make discovery fast with a unified map + list and curated POIs.
Enable realistic itineraries with route time estimates.
Ship an ownable brand identity that feels modern and friendly.

process.title: Discovery
process.note: Interviewed 12 travelers; mapped key pains: scattered info, time estimates, offline notes.

process.title: Branding
process.note: Logo, color system, typography; visual language inspired by Japanese wayfinding.

process.title: IA & Flows
process.note: Search → Save → Itinerary; reduced steps and kept map context persistent.

process.title: Design System
process.note: Tokens, components, states; responsive specs and accessibility contrast.

process.title: Build
process.note: React UI + Maps, collections/favorites, cached place details, offline notes.

process.title: Validate
process.note: MVP tested with 12 travelers; strong interest in the itinerary flow.

process.title: Launch Prep
process.note: Landing page, content plan, social snippets, merch concepts.

responsibilities: Brand identity — logo, palette, typography, usage rules.
End-to-end product design (IA, flows, components, states).
React UI with accessible, responsive components.
Maps: POIs, routing, time estimates, collections & favorites.
Offline notes and cached place details.
Launch assets: landing, visuals, and merch concepts.
problems: Travel info is scattered across tabs; users lose context switching between map and lists.
Route planning lacks realistic time estimates, causing rushed schedules.
Saving places and notes for offline use is unreliable.
solutions: Unified map + list UI with curated POIs and quick filters.
Day-by-day itineraries with route time estimates and pacing nudges.
Lightweight offline notes and cached place details for saved items.
marketing: Landing page with clear value props and itinerary demo.
SEO content: neighborhood guides and themed lists.
Social snippets highlighting saved collections & offline notes.
metrics: Repeat visits from users building multi-day itineraries.
Saved collections correlated with return usage.
outcomes: MVP validated with 12 travelers; strong interest in itinerary flow.
Roadmap clear for budgets, rail passes, and shareable trips.
nextSteps: Budget planning and export to PDF.
JR Pass and Suica card helpers.

robol.title: Robol Solutions
robol.subtitle: Marketing site — design system + developer handoff
robol.summary: I designed a compact design system in Figma (tokens, components, variants) and worked closely with developers to ship a clean, responsive marketing site fast.
responsibilities: Audit + define brand typography, color, and spacing tokens
Build reusable components (nav, hero, feature cards, CTA)
Create responsive specs; annotate states and breakpoints
problems: Inconsistent UI across pages due to ad-hoc components
Design-to-dev handoff slowed by unclear specs and states
solutions: Token-based design system with reusable, documented components
Clear responsive specs + annotated states; tight async reviews
outcomes: Reduced rework: devs reused components across 6 pages
Faster iteration; consistent visuals + accessible contrast
